comment_text.mn13:3.1: This group of three—kāma, rūpa, vedanā—is also found at AN 3.126 and AN 10.29, where it also relates to the teachings of outsiders.
comment_text.mn13:3.3: The text does not say what the wanderers understood by these three full understandings. The commentary says they spoke in reference to, respectively, the first absorption, the formless attainments, and the non-percipient state.
comment_text.mn13:3.4: In questioning this, the wanderers display better discernment than many today, who leap all too readily from the discovery of something in common between religions to the assertion that they are therefore the same.
comment_text.mn13:4.3: This is the quintessential Buddhist attitude when encountering something unknown: to neither accept nor reject, but inquire.
comment_text.mn13:6.2: This set of three questions is a key analytical approach in the suttas. Without an appreciation of both the good and bad sides of things we cannot properly understand them and be free of craving for them.
comment_text.mn13:13.1: Bastions were “wetly plastered” (addāvalepana) for resistance from fire (SN 35.243:7.1).
comment_text.mn13:13.2: For “splashed with dung” (chakaṇakāyapi osiñcanti), PTS reads pakkaṭṭhī, but this word appears to be spurious. The commentary says chakaṇakā means “boiling cowdung”, but nothing in the word itself suggests “boiling”. The Chinese parallels at MA 99 and T 53 have “molten copper” 融銅, while EA 21.9 has “molten iron” (消鐵). | Abhivagga is only found here in Pali. The Atharvaveda (3.5.2, 6.54.2, 11.2.4) has abhīvarga apparently in the sense of “domain”. The commentary says abhivagga was a “hundred-toothed” weapon that crushed invaders of a castle. However, vagga has the recognized military sense of “cadre, company, platoon”, so I take abhivagga to mean “superior force”.
comment_text.mn13:14.3: The commentary explains these punishments thus. “Porridge pot”: remove the top of the skull and drop in a hot iron ball so that the brains boil over. “Shell-shave”: grind the skull with gravel until it is smooth. “Rāhu”s mouth’: force open the mouth with a skewer, put in oil and wick, and light it so it burns like the sun swallowed by the titan Rāhu (SN 2.8). “Garland of fire”: smear the body with oil and set it alight. “Burning hand”: wrap the hand with oiled rags and set it alight. “Bulrush twist”: flay the skin from the neck down, then twist it into a band by which to hang the victim. “Bark dress”: cut the skin in strips and make it into a garment. “Antelope”: pin the bound victim to the ground and roast them alive. “Meat hook”: flay with double fish-hooks. “Coins”: slice off disks of flesh like coins. “Caustic pickle”: beat the victim, then rub the wounds with caustic solution. “Twisting bar”: pin the victim to the ground by the ears and twirl them by the feet. “Straw mat”: beat them until every bone is broken and the body becomes limp as a mattress.
comment_text.mn13:15.2: The drawbacks are escalating, the point being that hell is worse than the punishments described above.
comment_text.mn13:15.3: Previous drawbacks pertained to what is “apparent in this very life” (sandiṭṭhika), whereas this applies to “lives to come” (samparāyika).
comment_text.mn13:16.2: This happens with the realization of non-return.
comment_text.mn13:21.1: As shown in MN 10:14.3, this meditation proceeds not by objectifying the other’s corpse as repulsive, but by identifying “it”—the neuter-gendered sarīra—with one’s own body.
comment_text.mn13:30.2: Since “forms” also includes the refined visions of meditation, the full understanding of forms only occurs with arahantship.
comment_text.mn13:32.2: The Buddha illustrates “feelings” with the highest and most refined possible feelings, those of jhāna.
comment_text.mn13:36.2: This describes the stage of insight meditation. After the meditator has attained absorption, they reflect that even those sublime feelings are impermanent.

root_text.mn13:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn13:2.1: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisiṁsu.
root_text.mn13:2.4: yaṁ nūna mayaṁ yena aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyāmā”ti.
root_text.mn13:2.5: Atha kho te bhikkhū yena aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ārāmo tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu;
root_text.mn13:2.6: sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinne kho te bhikkhū te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn13:3.1: “samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo kāmānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapeti, mayampi kāmānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapema;
root_text.mn13:3.2: samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo rūpānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapeti, mayampi rūpānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapema;
root_text.mn13:3.3: samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo vedanānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapeti, mayampi vedanānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapema;
root_text.mn13:3.4: idha no, āvuso, ko viseso, ko adhippayāso, kiṁ nānākaraṇaṁ samaṇassa vā gotamassa amhākaṁ vā—
root_text.mn13:3.5: yadidaṁ dhammadesanāya vā dhammadesanaṁ, anusāsaniyā vā anusāsanin”ti?
root_text.mn13:4.1: Atha kho te bhikkhū tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁsu, nappaṭikkosiṁsu;
root_text.mn13:5.1: Atha kho te bhikkhū sāvatthiyaṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn13:5.2: “idha mayaṁ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisimha.
root_text.mn13:5.5: yaṁ nūna mayaṁ yena aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyāmā’ti.
root_text.mn13:5.6: Atha kho mayaṁ, bhante, yena aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ ārāmo tenupasaṅkamimha; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṁ sammodimha;
root_text.mn13:5.7: sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdimha. Ekamantaṁ nisinne kho amhe, bhante, te aññatitthiyā paribbājakā etadavocuṁ:
root_text.mn13:5.8: ‘samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo kāmānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapeti, mayampi kāmānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapema.
root_text.mn13:5.9: Samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo rūpānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapeti, mayampi rūpānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapema.
root_text.mn13:5.10: Samaṇo, āvuso, gotamo vedanānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapeti, mayampi vedanānaṁ pariññaṁ paññapema.
root_text.mn13:5.11: Idha no, āvuso, ko viseso, ko adhippayāso, kiṁ nānākaraṇaṁ samaṇassa vā gotamassa amhākaṁ vā, yadidaṁ dhammadesanāya vā dhammadesanaṁ anusāsaniyā vā anusāsanin’ti.
root_text.mn13:5.12: Atha kho mayaṁ, bhante, tesaṁ aññatitthiyānaṁ paribbājakānaṁ bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandimha, nappaṭikkosimha;
root_text.mn13:6.2: ‘ko panāvuso, kāmānaṁ assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṁ nissaraṇaṁ?
root_text.mn13:6.3: Ko rūpānaṁ assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṁ nissaraṇaṁ?
root_text.mn13:6.4: Ko vedanānaṁ assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṁ nissaraṇan’ti?
root_text.mn13:6.5: Evaṁ puṭṭhā, bhikkhave, aññatitthiyā paribbājakā na ceva sampāyissanti, uttariñca vighātaṁ āpajjissanti.
root_text.mn13:6.8: Nāhaṁ taṁ, bhikkhave, passāmi sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya yo imesaṁ pañhānaṁ veyyākaraṇena cittaṁ ārādheyya, aññatra tathāgatena vā tathāgatasāvakena vā, ito vā pana sutvā.
root_text.mn13:7.4: Cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā,
root_text.mn13:7.8: kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā iṭṭhā kantā manāpā piyarūpā kāmūpasaṁhitā rajanīyā—
root_text.mn13:7.10: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, ime pañca kāmaguṇe paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ—ayaṁ kāmānaṁ assādo.
root_text.mn13:8.2: Idha, bhikkhave, kulaputto yena sippaṭṭhānena jīvikaṁ kappeti—
root_text.mn13:8.3: yadi muddāya yadi gaṇanāya yadi saṅkhānena yadi kasiyā yadi vaṇijjāya yadi gorakkhena yadi issatthena yadi rājaporisena yadi sippaññatarena—
root_text.mn13:8.4: sītassa purakkhato uṇhassa purakkhato ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassehi rissamāno khuppipāsāya mīyamāno;
root_text.mn13:8.5: ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn13:9.1: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, kulaputtassa evaṁ uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato te bhogā nābhinipphajjanti.
root_text.mn13:9.2: So socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati, sammohaṁ āpajjati:
root_text.mn13:9.3: ‘moghaṁ vata me uṭṭhānaṁ, aphalo vata me vāyāmo’ti.
root_text.mn13:9.4: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn13:10.1: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, kulaputtassa evaṁ uṭṭhahato ghaṭato vāyamato te bhogā abhinipphajjanti.
root_text.mn13:10.2: So tesaṁ bhogānaṁ ārakkhādhikaraṇaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti:
root_text.mn13:10.3: ‘kinti me bhoge neva rājāno hareyyuṁ, na corā hareyyuṁ, na aggi daheyya, na udakaṁ vaheyya, na appiyā dāyādā hareyyun’ti.
root_text.mn13:10.4: Tassa evaṁ ārakkhato gopayato te bhoge rājāno vā haranti, corā vā haranti, aggi vā dahati, udakaṁ vā vahati, appiyā vā dāyādā haranti.
root_text.mn13:10.5: So socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṁ kandati, sammohaṁ āpajjati:
root_text.mn13:10.7: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn13:11.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu rājānopi rājūhi vivadanti, khattiyāpi khattiyehi vivadanti, brāhmaṇāpi brāhmaṇehi vivadanti, gahapatīpi gahapatīhi vivadanti, mātāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi mātarā vivadati, pitāpi puttena vivadati, puttopi pitarā vivadati, bhātāpi bhātarā vivadati, bhātāpi bhaginiyā vivadati, bhaginīpi bhātarā vivadati, sahāyopi sahāyena vivadati.
root_text.mn13:11.2: Te tattha kalahaviggahavivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ pāṇīhipi upakkamanti, leḍḍūhipi upakkamanti, daṇḍehipi upakkamanti, satthehipi upakkamanti.
root_text.mn13:11.3: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
root_text.mn13:11.4: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn13:12.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu asicammaṁ gahetvā, dhanukalāpaṁ sannayhitvā, ubhatobyūḷhaṁ saṅgāmaṁ pakkhandanti usūsupi khippamānesu, sattīsupi khippamānāsu, asīsupi vijjotalantesu.
root_text.mn13:12.2: Te tattha usūhipi vijjhanti, sattiyāpi vijjhanti, asināpi sīsaṁ chindanti.
root_text.mn13:12.3: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
root_text.mn13:12.4: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn13:13.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu asicammaṁ gahetvā, dhanukalāpaṁ sannayhitvā, addāvalepanā upakāriyo pakkhandanti usūsupi khippamānesu, sattīsupi khippamānāsu, asīsupi vijjotalantesu.
root_text.mn13:13.2: Te tattha usūhipi vijjhanti, sattiyāpi vijjhanti, chakaṇakāyapi osiñcanti, abhivaggenapi omaddanti, asināpi sīsaṁ chindanti.
root_text.mn13:13.3: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
root_text.mn13:13.4: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn13:14.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu sandhimpi chindanti, nillopampi haranti, ekāgārikampi karonti, paripanthepi tiṭṭhanti, paradārampi gacchanti.
root_text.mn13:14.2: Tamenaṁ rājāno gahetvā vividhā kammakāraṇā kārenti—
root_text.mn13:14.3: kasāhipi tāḷenti, vettehipi tāḷenti, aḍḍhadaṇḍakehipi tāḷenti; hatthampi chindanti, pādampi chindanti, hatthapādampi chindanti, kaṇṇampi chindanti, nāsampi chindanti, kaṇṇanāsampi chindanti; bilaṅgathālikampi karonti, saṅkhamuṇḍikampi karonti, rāhumukhampi karonti, jotimālikampi karonti, hatthapajjotikampi karonti, erakavattikampi karonti, cīrakavāsikampi karonti, eṇeyyakampi karonti, baḷisamaṁsikampi karonti, kahāpaṇikampi karonti, khārāpatacchikampi karonti, palighaparivattikampi karonti, palālapīṭhakampi karonti, tattenapi telena osiñcanti, sunakhehipi khādāpenti, jīvantampi sūle uttāsenti, asināpi sīsaṁ chindanti.
root_text.mn13:14.4: Te tattha maraṇampi nigacchanti, maraṇamattampi dukkhaṁ.
root_text.mn13:14.5: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo sandiṭṭhiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn13:15.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu kāyena duccaritaṁ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṁ caranti, manasā duccaritaṁ caranti.
root_text.mn13:15.2: Te kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṁ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṁ caritvā, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjanti.
root_text.mn13:15.3: Ayampi, bhikkhave, kāmānaṁ ādīnavo samparāyiko, dukkhakkhandho kāmahetu kāmanidānaṁ kāmādhikaraṇaṁ kāmānameva hetu.
root_text.mn13:16.2: Yo kho, bhikkhave, kāmesu chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṁ—idaṁ kāmānaṁ nissaraṇaṁ.
root_text.mn13:17.1: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṁ kāmānaṁ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṁ nappajānanti te vata sāmaṁ vā kāme parijānissanti, paraṁ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno kāme parijānissatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn13:17.2: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṁ kāmānaṁ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṁ pajānanti, te vata sāmaṁ vā kāme parijānissanti paraṁ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno kāme parijānissatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn13:18.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, khattiyakaññā vā brāhmaṇakaññā vā gahapatikaññā vā pannarasavassuddesikā vā soḷasavassuddesikā vā, nātidīghā nātirassā nātikisā nātithūlā nātikāḷī nāccodātā paramā sā, bhikkhave, tasmiṁ samaye subhā vaṇṇanibhāti?
root_text.mn13:18.4: Yaṁ kho, bhikkhave, subhaṁ vaṇṇanibhaṁ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ—
root_text.mn13:19.2: Idha, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṁ passeyya aparena samayena āsītikaṁ vā nāvutikaṁ vā vassasatikaṁ vā jātiyā, jiṇṇaṁ gopānasivaṅkaṁ bhoggaṁ daṇḍaparāyanaṁ pavedhamānaṁ gacchantiṁ āturaṁ gatayobbanaṁ khaṇḍadantaṁ palitakesaṁ, vilūnaṁ khalitasiraṁ valinaṁ tilakāhatagattaṁ.
root_text.mn13:19.4: yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?

root_text.mn13:20.3: yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?

root_text.mn13:21.2: ekāhamataṁ vā dvīhamataṁ vā tīhamataṁ vā, uddhumātakaṁ vinīlakaṁ vipubbakajātaṁ.
root_text.mn13:21.4: yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?
root_text.mn13:22.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṁ passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ—
root_text.mn13:22.2: kākehi vā khajjamānaṁ, kulalehi vā khajjamānaṁ, gijjhehi vā khajjamānaṁ, kaṅkehi vā khajjamānaṁ, sunakhehi vā khajjamānaṁ, byagghehi vā khajjamānaṁ, dīpīhi vā khajjamānaṁ, siṅgālehi vā khajjamānaṁ, vividhehi vā pāṇakajātehi khajjamānaṁ.
root_text.mn13:22.3: Taṁ kiṁ maññatha, bhikkhave, yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?

root_text.mn13:23-28.4: Taṁ kiṁ maññatha, bhikkhave, yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?
root_text.mn13:29.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, tameva bhaginiṁ passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ—
root_text.mn13:29.2: aṭṭhikāni setāni saṅkhavaṇṇapaṭibhāgāni, aṭṭhikāni puñjakitāni terovassikāni, aṭṭhikāni pūtīni cuṇṇakajātāni.
root_text.mn13:29.4: yā purimā subhā vaṇṇanibhā sā antarahitā, ādīnavo pātubhūtoti?
root_text.mn13:30.2: Yo, bhikkhave, rūpesu chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṁ—idaṁ rūpānaṁ nissaraṇaṁ.
root_text.mn13:31.1: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṁ rūpānaṁ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṁ nappajānanti te vata sāmaṁ vā rūpe parijānissanti, paraṁ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno rūpe parijānissatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn13:31.2: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṁ rūpānaṁ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṁ pajānanti te vata sāmaṁ vā rūpe parijānissanti paraṁ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno rūpe parijānissatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn13:32.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
root_text.mn13:32.3: Yasmiṁ samaye, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati, neva tasmiṁ samaye attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti;
root_text.mn13:33-35.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
root_text.mn13:33-35.2: yasmiṁ samaye, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā, upekkhako ca viharati, sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati …pe…
root_text.mn13:33-35.3: yasmiṁ samaye, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati, neva tasmiṁ samaye attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti;
root_text.mn13:36.2: Yaṁ, bhikkhave, vedanā aniccā dukkhā vipariṇāmadhammā—ayaṁ vedanānaṁ ādīnavo.
root_text.mn13:37.2: Yo, bhikkhave, vedanāsu chandarāgavinayo, chandarāgappahānaṁ—idaṁ vedanānaṁ nissaraṇaṁ.
root_text.mn13:38.1: Ye hi keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṁ vedanānaṁ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṁ nappajānanti, te vata sāmaṁ vā vedanaṁ parijānissanti, paraṁ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno vedanaṁ parijānissatīti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
root_text.mn13:38.2: Ye ca kho keci, bhikkhave, samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā evaṁ vedanānaṁ assādañca assādato ādīnavañca ādīnavato nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṁ pajānanti te vata sāmaṁ vā vedanaṁ parijānissanti, paraṁ vā tathattāya samādapessanti yathā paṭipanno vedanaṁ parijānissatīti—ṭhānametaṁ vijjatī”ti.
root_text.mn13:38.4: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn13:0.2: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
translation_text.mn13:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn13:2.1: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
translation_text.mn13:2.3: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.
translation_text.mn13:2.4: Why don’t we visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?”
translation_text.mn13:2.5: Then they went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.
translation_text.mn13:2.6: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. The wanderers said to them:
translation_text.mn13:3.1: “Reverends, the ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, and so do we.
translation_text.mn13:3.2: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of forms, and so do we.
translation_text.mn13:3.3: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of feelings, and so do we.
translation_text.mn13:3.4: What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s teaching and instruction and ours?”
translation_text.mn13:4.1: Those mendicants neither approved nor rejected that statement of the wanderers of other religions.
translation_text.mn13:4.2: They got up from their seat, thinking,
translation_text.mn13:4.3: “We will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”
translation_text.mn13:5.1: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said:
translation_text.mn13:6.1: “Mendicants, when wanderers of other religions say this, you should say to them:
translation_text.mn13:6.2: ‘But reverends, what’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to sensual pleasures?
translation_text.mn13:6.3: What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to forms?
translation_text.mn13:6.4: What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to feelings?’
translation_text.mn13:6.5: Questioned like this, the wanderers of other religions would be stumped, and, in addition, would get frustrated.
translation_text.mn13:6.7: Because they’re out of their element.
translation_text.mn13:6.8: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to these questions except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.
translation_text.mn13:7.1: And what is the gratification of sensual pleasures?
translation_text.mn13:7.2: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn13:7.4: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn13:7.8: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
translation_text.mn13:7.9: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
translation_text.mn13:7.10: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation: this is the gratification of sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:8.1: And what is the drawback of sensual pleasures?
translation_text.mn13:8.2: It’s when a gentleman earns a living by means such as
translation_text.mn13:8.3: arithmetic, accounting, calculating, farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions.
translation_text.mn13:8.4: But they must face cold and heat, being hurt by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles, and risking death from hunger and thirst.
translation_text.mn13:8.5: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:9.1: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, but fail to accrue  money.
translation_text.mn13:9.2: If this happens, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion, saying:
translation_text.mn13:9.3: ‘Oh, my hard work is wasted. My efforts are fruitless!’
translation_text.mn13:9.4: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:10.1: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, and succeed in earning money.
translation_text.mn13:10.2: But they experience pain and sadness when they try to protect it, thinking:
translation_text.mn13:10.3: ‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’
translation_text.mn13:10.4: And even though they protect it and ward it, rulers or bandits take it, or fire consumes it, or flood sweeps it away, or unloved heirs take it.
translation_text.mn13:10.5: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion:
translation_text.mn13:10.7: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:11.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend.
translation_text.mn13:11.2: Once they’ve started quarreling, arguing, and disputing, they attack each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords,
translation_text.mn13:11.3: resulting in death and deadly pain.
translation_text.mn13:11.4: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:12.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and plunge into a battle massed on both sides, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
translation_text.mn13:12.2: There they are struck with arrows and spears, and their heads are chopped off,
translation_text.mn13:12.3: resulting in death and deadly pain.
translation_text.mn13:12.4: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:13.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and charge wetly plastered bastions, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
translation_text.mn13:13.2: There they are struck with arrows and spears, splashed with dung, crushed by a superior force, and their heads are chopped off,
translation_text.mn13:13.3: resulting in death and deadly pain.
translation_text.mn13:13.4: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:14.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, and commit adultery.
translation_text.mn13:14.2: The rulers would arrest them and subject them to various punishments—
translation_text.mn13:14.3: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the hounds, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.
translation_text.mn13:14.4: These result in death and deadly pain.
translation_text.mn13:14.5: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:15.1: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures, they conduct themselves badly by way of body, speech, and mind.
translation_text.mn13:15.2: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
translation_text.mn13:15.3: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:16.1: And what is the escape from sensual pleasures?
translation_text.mn13:16.2: Removing and giving up desire and greed for sensual pleasures: this is the escape from sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:17.1: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:17.2: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures.
translation_text.mn13:18.1: And what is the gratification of forms?
translation_text.mn13:18.2: Suppose there was a girl of the brahmins, aristocrats, or householders in her fifteenth or sixteenth year, neither too tall nor too short, neither too thin nor too fat, neither too dark nor too fair. Is she not at the height of her beauty and prettiness?”
translation_text.mn13:18.4: “The pleasure and happiness that arise from this beauty and prettiness
translation_text.mn13:19.1: And what is the drawback of forms?
translation_text.mn13:19.2: Suppose that some time later you were to see that same sister—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy.
translation_text.mn13:19.4: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
translation_text.mn13:20.1: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in her own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others.
translation_text.mn13:20.3: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
translation_text.mn13:20.5: “This too is the drawback of forms.
translation_text.mn13:21.1: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
translation_text.mn13:21.4: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
translation_text.mn13:21.6: “This too is the drawback of forms.
translation_text.mn13:22.1: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it was being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures …
translation_text.mn13:23-28.1: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground.
translation_text.mn13:23-28.2: And it had been reduced to a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews … a skeleton rid of flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews … a skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …
translation_text.mn13:23-28.3: bones rid of sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here an ankle bone, there a shin-bone, here a thigh-bone, there a hip-bone, here a rib-bone, there a back-bone, here an arm-bone, there a neck-bone, here a jaw-bone, there a tooth, here the skull. …
translation_text.mn13:29.1: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground.
translation_text.mn13:29.2: And it had been reduced to white bones, the color of shells … decrepit bones, heaped in a pile … bones rotted and crumbled to powder.
translation_text.mn13:29.4: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
translation_text.mn13:29.6: “This too is the drawback of forms.
translation_text.mn13:30.1: And what is the escape from forms?
translation_text.mn13:30.2: Removing and giving up desire and greed for forms: this is the escape from forms.
translation_text.mn13:31.1: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand forms’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand forms themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand forms.
translation_text.mn13:31.2: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand forms’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand forms themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand forms.
translation_text.mn13:32.1: And what is the gratification of feelings?
translation_text.mn13:32.2: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
translation_text.mn13:32.3: At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both;
translation_text.mn13:32.4: they feel only feelings that are not hurtful.
translation_text.mn13:32.5: Freedom from being hurt is the ultimate gratification of feelings, I say.
translation_text.mn13:33-35.1: Furthermore, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …
translation_text.mn13:33-35.3: fourth absorption. At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both;
translation_text.mn13:33-35.4: they feel only feelings that are not hurtful.
translation_text.mn13:33-35.5: Freedom from being hurt is the ultimate gratification of feelings, I say.
translation_text.mn13:36.1: And what is the drawback of feelings?
translation_text.mn13:36.2: That feelings are impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is their drawback.
translation_text.mn13:37.1: And what is the escape from feelings?
translation_text.mn13:37.2: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feelings: this is the escape from feelings.
translation_text.mn13:38.1: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand feelings themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand feelings.
translation_text.mn13:38.2: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand feelings’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand feelings themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand feelings.”
translation_text.mn13:38.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn13:38.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
